content: *single_crochet increase 2sc* repeat until the end of the round slip_stitch into 1st single_crochet of the round 32 5 ch1 32 single_crochet single_crochet around slip_stitch into 1st single_crochet of the round 32 fasten_off leaving a short tail if using hot glue gun long tail if sewing assembly step 1 glue or sew the safety pin to the right side of the sepal step 2 tuck the ends from making the main sunflower body into the flower centre you can keep these in place with a blob of hot glue step 3 apply glue around the edge of the wrong side of the sepal and attach onto the back of the flower covering the back with the ends step 4 weave in any remaining ends the sunflower lanyard is a way to show people that you have a hidden disability it was created at gatwick airport in 2016 to make staff more aware of those who may need some extra time or support the sunflower lanyard is now recognised world-wide and is used across all types of public spaces the sunflower is discreet but also bright and easily visible to make it clear when someone is wearing one there are many reasons someone may wear a sunflower lanyard including chronic illness visual impairment anxiety neurodiversity it s important to be aware what the sunflower means to support people but also to be respectful and not question why they are wearing it for me i personally wear mine because i m autistic have adhd and anxiety the sunflower lanyard has made travel a lot more accessible to me having people ask if i need assistance or give me extra time makes all the difference follow emily s journey with -emily maunder neurodiversity on instagram and tiktok @emilyemaunder
